children.name: betray a friend or sb who trusts you
betray
children.definition: to be disloyal to your friends or to sb who trusts you, often causing serious harm to them as a result: phản bội, bán đứng
examples: He betrayed his friends in order to save his own life.
betray sb to the police/ government etcgive the police etc information about sb : bán đứng ai cho cảnh sát/ chính phủ
Olga’s best friend betrayed her to the secret police.
betray sb’s trust/ confidence/ friendship etcbetray sb who trusts you
I still have bitter feelings for Robert. What can I say? He completely betrayed my trust.
feel betrayedfeel that sb you trust has betrayed you
When I heard what she had said about me I felt angry and betrayed.
betrayal[S or U noun] when sb betrays another person: phản bội
a powerful story of love and betrayal set in the tranquil world of Cambridge University
The family regard her marriage to a non-Muslim as a betrayal.
betrayal of sb’s trust/ friendship/ confidence etc
What Evans did amounts to a betrayal of the trust placed in him by the company.

children.name: stab sb in the back
children.definition: to betray sb who trusts you, especially sb that you work with, by saying or doing sth that will cause them a lot of harm and get you an advantage: đâm sau lưng ai
examples: backstabbing[U noun]
I’m not sorry to be away from the gossip and backstabbing of the office.

children.name: He seems friendly, but he wouldn’t hesitate to stab you in the back if he thought it would help him get your job
examples: Thatcher was stabbed in the back by her former friends and colleagues in the Conservative Party.

children.name: sell sb down the river
children.definition: to betray a group of people who trusted you to help them, in order to gain money or power for yourself: bán đứng ai đó
examples: The workers were promised that they would not lose their jobs as a result of the merger. Later they found out that they had been sold down the river.

children.name: treachery
children.definition: great disloyalty to sb who trusts you, for example by secretly tricking them, or helping their enemies: sự phản bội, sự phụ bạc, sự bội bạc
examples: When the king learned of his brother’s treachery, he quickly ordered his execution.
After a furious argument during which he accused the prime minister of treachery, he announced that he would resign his Cabinet position.
Corley said she was standing down as leader because of the treachery of her own colleagues.

children.name: betray
children.definition: to be disloyal to your country, for example by helping its enemies or giving them secret information: phản bội
examples: The former federal agent betrayed his country and gave away vital military secrets.
betrayal[C or U noun]sự phản bội
act of betrayal
Paisley described government plans to separate Northern Ireland from the United Kingdom as an act of betrayal.

children.name: collaborate
children.definition: to betray your country by helping its enemies when they have defeated your country and taken control of it: cộng tác với địch
examples: He was imprisoned in 1945 for collaborating with the enemy.
Anyone who was suspected of collaboratingwiththe occupying forces was arrested.

children.name: treason
children.definition: the crime of betraying your country by helping its enemies: tội phản quốc
examples: Fleming was flown to Washington and tried for treason
commit treason
All five of the men will be charged with committing treason against the state.
Guy Fawkes was executed for treason after he took part in a plot to blow up the British Parliament building.

children.name: disloyal
children.definition: /dɪsˈlɔɪəl/  not loyal to your friends, your country, or the group you belong to:
examples: không trung thành, phản bội
▪ Government MPs who voted against the bill were accused of being disloyal.
▪ She felt disloyal and ashamed of herself.
disloyal to
không trung thành với
▪ He didn’t want to be disloyal to his employer.
disloyaladjective không trung thành
not loyal; not supportingsomeone that you should support
_His sisters thought that his autobiography was disloyaltothe family.

children.name: treacherous
children.definition: /ˈtretʃərəs/  someone who is treacherous is extremely disloyal and cannot be trusted because they secretly intend to harm other people in order to get advantages for themselves:
examples: không trung thành, phản bội, không trung thực
▪ He knew he had been betrayed by a scheming and treacherous woman.
treacherousadjectiveNOT LOYALphản bội, phụ bạc, bội bạc; bội tín; bội trung; bất trung
mainly old use A person who is treacherous deceives someone who trusts them, or has no loyalty
_Vargas plays the part of a treacherous aristocrat who betrays his king and country.
_I feel a bit treacheroustomy own sex if I ever make general criticisms of women.

children.name: betray
children.definition: to behave in a way that is completely against your beliefs or principles, so that people think you have given them up completely: phản bội
examples: The new government has betrayed the ideals of the revolution.
Greene was denounced for betraying his Catholic beliefs and siding with the Communists.

children.name: sell out
children.definition: to behave in a way that is completely against what you have said are your beliefs or principles, especially in order to get advantages for yourself in politics: phản bội
examples: When the Socialists changed their policy on nuclear weapons they were accused of selling out.
Many of the radicals of the 1960s sold out - they became accountants and salesmen.

children.name: disloyalty
children.definition: /dɪsˈlɔɪəlti/  when someone behaves in a way that is not loyal to their friends, country, or the group they belong to:
examples: sự không trung thành
▪ Other party members accused Simpson of disloyalty.
disloyalty to
không trung thành với
▪ I knew they all hated me for my disloyalty to the family.

children.name: traitor
children.definition: /ˈtreɪtəʳ/  someone who helps the enemies of their country, for example by giving them secret information:
examples: kẻ phản bội
▪ At the end of the war Mata Hari was hanged as a traitor.
Cuối cuộc chiến, Mata Hari đã bị treo cổ vì phản bội
traitor to
phản bội (ai, cái gì)
▪ When he left Nicaragua for the US, he was denounced as a traitor to the revolution.
Khi anh ta rời khỏi Nicaragua đến Mỹ, anh ta đã bị tố giác phản bội cách mạng
turn traitorbecome a traitor
trở thành kẻ phản bội
▪ Zaragoza turned traitor when he thought the Republicans would lose the war.
zaragoza đã trở thành kẻ phản bội khi hắn nghĩ đảng Cộng hòa sẽ thua cuộc
traitornoun[ C ]disapproving kẻ phản bội (đất nước, bạn bè..)
a person who is not loyal or stops being loyal to their own country, social class, beliefs, etc.
_The leaders of the rebellion were hanged as traitors.
_The Chinese Communist Partybranded(= called) Mr Gorbachev 'a traitortosocialism'.

children.name: collaborator
children.definition: /kəˈlæbəreɪtəʳ/  someone who helps their country’s enemies, especially when the enemy has taken control of that country:
examples: Người cộng tác
▪ Women who were suspected of collaborating had their heads shaved in public.
những người phụ nữ bị nghi ngờ đã hợp tác với giặc bị cạo trọc đầu công khai
collaborator with
người cộng tác với ai
▪ His father had been accused of collaborating with the CIA.
Cha hắn đã bị buộc tội cộng tác với CIA
collaboratornoun[ C ]ENEMY SUPPORTERkẻ cộng tác với địch
disapprovinga person who works with an enemy who has taken control of their country
_wartime collaborators
_a Nazi collaborator
